BIOS776
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2025. The new module is developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that ISMIB MRes provision should concentrate on a single program spanning biological and biomedical pathways. We aim to offer an MRes program of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned with our strategic ambitions. In addition, this module will be offered to the MBiol (Integrated Masters). Currently, students take LIFE731, a module that will close from Sept 2025. In summary, this module will be made available to:
Integrated Masters (MBiol)[required]
Biotechnology MSc (part-time) MSc 2025-26 [optional]
Biological and Biomedical Sciences (full-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]
Advanced Biological and Biomedical Sciences (part-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]


Staffing and Expertise: Contributions to teaching will be predominantly from ISMIB and other institutes within FHLS .

Overview

Overview
This module is designed to provide students with the essential knowledge and interdisciplinary skills required to address some of the most urgent global challenges in the field of biosciences. The course empowers students to navigate complex scientific issues with a holistic and ethical mindset by exploring pivotal topics such as global health crises, sustainable development, and the role of public engagement in science. By combining scientific inquiry with an understanding of societal and environmental contexts, learners will be better equipped to propose solutions to real-world problems.
The module will be delivered through a combination of lectures, interactive workshops, and seminars. These formats will provide foundational knowledge and encourage active participation and deeper engagement with the material. Students will be motivated to independently explore the subjects, conduct their research, and develop skills in critical analysis by reviewing, evaluating, and interpreting a range of sources.
There will be two assessments: a group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study in which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.
Educational Aims
•To ensure students develop an understanding of current issues faced in the biosciences relating to research, sustainability and public engagement
•To develop students with an enhanced ability to communicate effectively in a range of settings
•To provide students with enhanced skills in critical thinking and problem-solving
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to equip students with the critical knowledge and interdisciplinary skills needed to tackle today's most pressing global challenges in the biosciences with a holistic and ethical perspective by exploring key topics, such as:
Global health challenges, including drug design and development, tissue engineering, and cancer research.
Sustainable development challenges, focusing on sustainability in biosciences research, the use of artificial intelligence, the impacts of climate change, and
Public engagement in science.

Through these topics, learners gain a comprehensive understanding of the intersections between science, sustainability, and ethics.

Students will be taught through seminars, in which experts will discuss a particular area of challenge in the biosciences. There will also be interactive workshops dedicated to the development of skills, in support of the module assignments, and online asynchronous material to support learning.
Outline Syllabus
Sessions will introduce a range of topics related to global challenges in the biosciences, catering to the needs of the diverse cohort. Topics might include:

Topics related to Health:
-Global healthcare challenges
-Drug design and development
-Antimicrobial Resistance

Topics related to the environment:
-Food security
-Biodiversity
-Climate change

Research ethics

Topics related to sustainability:
-Sustainability in Research
-Sustainability in Education
-Sustainability in AI

The following sessions will specifically guide students in relation to their assessment tasks:
-Public Engagement including challenges and benefits
-Preparing a poster
-How to create a digital case study
-Critical reading and writing
-Critical thinking and reflection

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to the availability of staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching method 1—Seminars (9 HOURS ): A series of nine seminars will cover a variety of topics addressing global challenges in the biosciences, tailored to meet the diverse needs of participants from various life science disciplines. These seminars, led by experts, will present cutting-edge material, offering an enriching platform for research-informed teaching.

Teaching method 2—Workshops (10 HOURS): 5 (2h) academic-led workshops will deliver content related to the development of skills required for interpreting high-level scientific content (i.e., critical thinking) and skills related to digital fluency (such as creating posters and animated videos).

Teaching Method 3 – Asynchronous online tutorials (4 HOURS) will provide comprehensive coverage of key topics related to Research Integrity and Ethics, allowing participants to engage with the material at their own pace. These tutorials will include a range of resources and interactive exercises to explore the complexities of ethical issues.

Teaching Method 4—Self-directed study. The self-study hours will include reading about the topics, researching and critically appraising articles on global challenges, time spent on group work and preparing for assignments, and exploring and practicing digital platforms. This will require adaptability and organizational skills.
Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module, as evidenced by this cohesive research-connected course, which enables active learning through working on real global issues and where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to current employability skills (effective communication, problem-solving, critical thinking, and analysis).

Research-Connected Teaching and Active Learning: Learning and teaching throughout this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists in molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology, ensuring that the latest research evidence informs teaching. In addressing global challenges in biosciences, such as emerging diseases, antimicrobial resistance, and personalized medicine, core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications from recent clinical and scientific research. Application-based sessions and workshops incorporate real-world examples that highlight the role of biosciences in tackling these global health issues, fostering a deeper understanding of both current challenges and cutting-edge solutions. The seminars and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Special attention has been given to designing and developing this module to ensure it is accessible and inclusive for all individuals. The content, topics, and case studies are tailored to be relevant for students from various life sciences disciplines, as well as for international students. Workshops will offer additional support on the covered topics and provide guidance for international students. These workshops will also offer formative feedback, allowing every student to improve their performance in assessments. Self-directed learning through interactive resources will enable students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of key course elements beforehand. All resource templates are designed with accessibility in mind to ensure ease of use for all. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module, emphasizing active participation and collaboration. Lectures are designed to be highly interactive and discursive, encouraging learners to engage in meaningful dialogue, contribute ideas, and critically analyse complex topics. Assessment 1 is centred around collaborative group work, where learners function as a cohesive team to plan, execute, and interpret complex global challenges. This collaborative process nurtures confidence and creates a supportive environment—a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas, expertise, and feedback. Additionally, completing a project and effectively
communicating the outcomes through group poster presentations helps students build confidence across a diverse range of skills, including teamwork, critical thinking, and public communication.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is part of a globally connected professional community, and this module reflects that by embedding the values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability throughout its learning and assessment activities. The learning materials prioritize diverse representation, incorporating scientific case studies from underrepresented communities and highlighting sustainable practices in the teaching and learning environment. The module also emphasizes a strong ethical focus, encouraging learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with particular attention to ethics relevant to their specific discipline.

Students will be informed that teaching plans may be subject to change in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics). Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each student informing them of any changes that prove necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There will be two assessments: A group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study for which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.

The assessments in this module address key areas in the University of Liverpool’s strategic framework for supporting the development of successful graduates, in particular in relation to developing digital skills, global citizenship and inclusivity. Both assignments require students to utilise digital skills, the first being a poster, and the second being production of an animated video. Students will have support in the form of formal training and formative feedback to aid the development of these digital skills, prior to the submission of these assessments. In relation to global citizenship, both assignments require students to consider challenges in the biosciences on a global scale and, in the case of the second assessment, to also provide solutions to the global issue they have chosen to explore, thus aiding them in becoming graduates with the ability to see challenges from a global perspective. The second assessment also requires students to reflect on the design of their animation from the perspective of creating inclusive content, again broadening their perspectives and their understanding of inclusive practices.

Assessment 1:
A group poster critiquing a public-facing science content.
Peer evaluation will be used as part of the marking.
Assessment 1 is worth 40% of the module mark.

Assessment 2:
This assessment is composed of two parts:
-A 3-5 minute animated digital case study outlining a current challenge faced in the biosciences and presenting possible solution(s) (worth 60% of the assessment 2 grade)
-A critical reflection on the design in relation to accessibility and clear messaging (worth 40% of the assessment 2 grade)
Assessment 2 is worth 60% of the module mark.
For both assessments, there will be an opportunity for formative feedback.
Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Reassessment strategy
There is a re-assessment opportunity for both assessments. For assessment 1, the poster will be an individual piece of work. For assessment 2, the format will be the same as the original. It will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

-Critical reading and writing
-Critical thinking and reflection

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to the availability of staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching method 1—Seminars (9 HOURS ): A series of nine seminars will cover a variety of topics addressing global challenges in the biosciences, tailored to meet the diverse needs of participants from various life science disciplines. These seminars, led by experts, will present cutting-edge material, offering an enriching platform for research-informed teaching.

Teaching method 2—Workshops (10 HOURS): 5 (2h) academic-led workshops will deliver content related to the development of skills required for interpreting high-level scientific content (i.e., critical thinking) and skills related to digital fluency (such as creating posters and animated videos).

Teaching Method 3 – Asynchronous online tutorials (4 HOURS) will provide comprehensive coverage of key topics related to Research Integrity and Ethics, allowing participants to engage with the material at their own pace. These tutorials will include a range of resources and interactive exercises to explore the complexities of ethical issues.

Teaching Method 4—Self-directed study. The self-study hours will include reading about the topics, researching and critically appraising articles on global challenges, time spent on group work and preparing for assignments, and exploring and practicing digital platforms. This will require adaptability and organizational skills.
Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module, as evidenced by this cohesive research-connected course, which enables active learning through working on real global issues and where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to current employability skills (effective communication, problem-solving, critical thinking, and analysis).

Research-Connected Teaching and Active Learning: Learning and teaching throughout this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists in molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology, ensuring that the latest research evidence informs teaching. In addressing global challenges in biosciences, such as emerging diseases, antimicrobial resistance, and personalized medicine, core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications from recent clinical and scientific research. Application-based sessions and workshops incorporate real-world examples that highlight the role of biosciences in tackling these global health issues, fostering a deeper understanding of both current challenges and cutting-edge solutions. The seminars and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Special attention has been given to designing and developing this module to ensure it is accessible and inclusive for all individuals. The content, topics, and case studies are tailored to be relevant for students from various life sciences disciplines, as well as for international students. Workshops will offer additional support on the covered topics and provide guidance for international students. These workshops will also offer formative feedback, allowing every student to improve their performance in assessments. Self-directed learning through interactive resources will enable students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of key course elements beforehand. All resource templates are designed with accessibility in mind to ensure ease of use for all. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module, emphasizing active participation and collaboration. Lectures are designed to be highly interactive and discursive, encouraging learners to engage in meaningful dialogue, contribute ideas, and critically analyse complex topics. Assessment 1 is centred around collaborative group work, where learners function as a cohesive team to plan, execute, and interpret complex global challenges. This collaborative process nurtures confidence and creates a supportive environment—a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas, expertise, and feedback. Additionally, completing a project and effectively
communicating the outcomes through group poster presentations helps students build confidence across a diverse range of skills, including teamwork, critical thinking, and public communication.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is part of a globally connected professional community, and this module reflects that by embedding the values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability throughout its learning and assessment activities. The learning materials prioritize diverse representation, incorporating scientific case studies from underrepresented communities and highlighting sustainable practices in the teaching and learning environment. The module also emphasizes a strong ethical focus, encouraging learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with particular attention to ethics relevant to their specific discipline.

Students will be informed that teaching plans may be subject to change in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics). Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each student informing them of any changes that prove necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There will be two assessments: A group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study for which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.

The assessments in this module address key areas in the University of Liverpool’s strategic framework for supporting the development of successful graduates, in particular in relation to developing digital skills, global citizenship and inclusivity. Both assignments require students to utilise digital skills, the first being a poster, and the second being production of an animated video. Students will have support in the form of formal training and formative feedback to aid the development of these digital skills, prior to the submission of these assessments. In relation to global citizenship, both assignments require students to consider challenges in the biosciences on a global scale and, in the case of the second assessment, to also provide solutions to the global issue they have chosen to explore, thus aiding them in becoming graduates with the ability to see challenges from a global perspective. The second assessment also requires students to reflect on the design of their animation from the perspective of creating inclusive content, again broadening their perspectives and their understanding of inclusive practices.

Assessment 1:
A group poster critiquing a public-facing science content.
Peer evaluation will be used as part of the marking.
Assessment 1 is worth 40% of the module mark.

Assessment 2:
This assessment is composed of two parts:
-A 3-5 minute animated digital case study outlining a current challenge faced in the biosciences and presenting possible solution(s) (worth 60% of the assessment 2 grade)
-A critical reflection on the design in relation to accessibility and clear messaging (worth 40% of the assessment 2 grade)
Assessment 2 is worth 60% of the module mark.
For both assessments, there will be an opportunity for formative feedback.
Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Reassessment strategy
There is a re-assessment opportunity for both assessments. For assessment 1, the poster will be an individual piece of work. For assessment 2, the format will be the same as the original. It will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2025. The new module is developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that ISMIB MRes provision should concentrate on a single program spanning biological and biomedical pathways. We aim to offer an MRes program of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned with our strategic ambitions. In addition, this module will be offered to the MBiol (Integrated Masters). Currently, students take LIFE731, a module that will close from Sept 2025. In summary, this module will be made available to:
Integrated Masters (MBiol)[required]
Biotechnology MSc (part-time) MSc 2025-26 [optional]
Biological and Biomedical Sciences (full-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]
Advanced Biological and Biomedical Sciences (part-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]


Staffing and Expertise: Contributions to teaching will be predominantly from ISMIB and other institutes within FHLS .

Overview

Overview
This module is designed to provide students with the essential knowledge and interdisciplinary skills required to address some of the most urgent global challenges in the field of biosciences. The course empowers students to navigate complex scientific issues with a holistic and ethical mindset by exploring pivotal topics such as global health crises, sustainable development, and the role of public engagement in science. By combining scientific inquiry with an understanding of societal and environmental contexts, learners will be better equipped to propose solutions to real-world problems.
The module will be delivered through a combination of lectures, interactive workshops, and seminars. These formats will provide foundational knowledge and encourage active participation and deeper engagement with the material. Students will be motivated to independently explore the subjects, conduct their research, and develop skills in critical analysis by reviewing, evaluating, and interpreting a range of sources.
There will be two assessments: a group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study in which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.
Educational Aims
•To ensure students develop an understanding of current issues faced in the biosciences relating to research, sustainability and public engagement
•To develop students with an enhanced ability to communicate effectively in a range of settings
•To provide students with enhanced skills in critical thinking and problem-solving
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to equip students with the critical knowledge and interdisciplinary skills needed to tackle today's most pressing global challenges in the biosciences with a holistic and ethical perspective by exploring key topics, such as:
Global health challenges, including drug design and development, tissue engineering, and cancer research.
Sustainable development challenges, focusing on sustainability in biosciences research, the use of artificial intelligence, the impacts of climate change, and
Public engagement in science.

Through these topics, learners gain a comprehensive understanding of the intersections between science, sustainability, and ethics.

Students will be taught through seminars, in which experts will discuss a particular area of challenge in the biosciences. There will also be interactive workshops dedicated to the development of skills, in support of the module assignments, and online asynchronous material to support learning.
Outline Syllabus
Sessions will introduce a range of topics related to global challenges in the biosciences, catering to the needs of the diverse cohort. Topics might include:

Topics related to Health:
-Global healthcare challenges
-Drug design and development
-Antimicrobial Resistance

Topics related to the environment:
-Food security
-Biodiversity
-Climate change

Research ethics

Topics related to sustainability:
-Sustainability in Research
-Sustainability in Education
-Sustainability in AI

The following sessions will specifically guide students in relation to their assessment tasks:
-Public Engagement including challenges and benefits
-Preparing a poster
-How to create a digital case study
-Critical reading and writing
-Critical thinking and reflection

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to the availability of staff expertise.

Teaching method 1—Seminars (9 HOURS ): A series of nine seminars will cover a variety of topics addressing global challenges in the biosciences, tailored to meet the diverse needs of participants from various life science disciplines. Teaching Method 4—Self-directed study. This will require adaptability and organizational skills.

A group poster critiquing a public-facing science content.
Peer evaluation will be used as part of the marking.
Assessment 1 is worth 40% of the module mark.

Assessment 2:
This assessment is composed of two parts:
-A 3-5 minute animated digital case study outlining a current challenge faced in the biosciences and presenting possible solution(s) (worth 60% of the assessment 2 grade)
-A critical reflection on the design in relation to accessibility and clear messaging (worth 40% of the assessment 2 grade)
Assessment 2 is worth 60% of the module mark.
For both assessments, there will be an opportunity for formative feedback.
Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Reassessment strategy
There is a re-assessment opportunity for both assessments. For assessment 1, the poster will be an individual piece of work. For assessment 2, the format will be the same as the original. It will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2025. The new module is developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that ISMIB MRes provision should concentrate on a single program spanning biological and biomedical pathways. We aim to offer an MRes program of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned with our strategic ambitions. In addition, this module will be offered to the MBiol (Integrated Masters). Currently, students take LIFE731, a module that will close from Sept 2025. In summary, this module will be made available to:
Integrated Masters (MBiol)[required]
Biotechnology MSc (part-time) MSc 2025-26 [optional]
Biological and Biomedical Sciences (full-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]
Advanced Biological and Biomedical Sciences (part-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]


Staffing and Expertise: Contributions to teaching will be predominantly from ISMIB and other institutes within FHLS .

Overview

Overview
This module is designed to provide students with the essential knowledge and interdisciplinary skills required to address some of the most urgent global challenges in the field of biosciences. The course empowers students to navigate complex scientific issues with a holistic and ethical mindset by exploring pivotal topics such as global health crises, sustainable development, and the role of public engagement in science. By combining scientific inquiry with an understanding of societal and environmental contexts, learners will be better equipped to propose solutions to real-world problems.
The module will be delivered through a combination of lectures, interactive workshops, and seminars. These formats will provide foundational knowledge and encourage active participation and deeper engagement with the material. Students will be motivated to independently explore the subjects, conduct their research, and develop skills in critical analysis by reviewing, evaluating, and interpreting a range of sources.
There will be two assessments: a group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study in which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.
Educational Aims
•To ensure students develop an understanding of current issues faced in the biosciences relating to research, sustainability and public engagement
•To develop students with an enhanced ability to communicate effectively in a range of settings
•To provide students with enhanced skills in critical thinking and problem-solving
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to equip students with the critical knowledge and interdisciplinary skills needed to tackle today's most pressing global challenges in the biosciences with a holistic and ethical perspective by exploring key topics, such as:
Global health challenges, including drug design and development, tissue engineering, and cancer research.
Sustainable development challenges, focusing on sustainability in biosciences research, the use of artificial intelligence, the impacts of climate change, and
Public engagement in science.

Through these topics, learners gain a comprehensive understanding of the intersections between science, sustainability, and ethics.

Students will be taught through seminars, in which experts will discuss a particular area of challenge in the biosciences. There will also be interactive workshops dedicated to the development of skills, in support of the module assignments, and online asynchronous material to support learning.
Outline Syllabus
Sessions will introduce a range of topics related to global challenges in the biosciences, catering to the needs of the diverse cohort. Topics might include:

Topics related to Health:
-Global healthcare challenges
-Drug design and development
-Antimicrobial Resistance

Topics related to the environment:
-Food security
-Biodiversity
-Climate change

Research ethics

Topics related to sustainability:
-Sustainability in Research
-Sustainability in Education
-Sustainability in AI

The following sessions will specifically guide students in relation to their assessment tasks:
-Public Engagement including challenges and benefits
-Preparing a poster
-How to create a digital case study
-Critical reading and writing
-Critical thinking and reflection

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to the availability of staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching method 1—Seminars (9 HOURS ): A series of nine seminars will cover a variety of topics addressing global challenges in the biosciences, tailored to meet the diverse needs of participants from various life science disciplines. These seminars, led by experts, will present cutting-edge material, offering an enriching platform for research-informed teaching.

Teaching method 2—Workshops (10 HOURS): 5 (2h) academic-led workshops will deliver content related to the development of skills required for interpreting high-level scientific content (i.e., critical thinking) and skills related to digital fluency (such as creating posters and animated videos).

Teaching Method 3 – Asynchronous online tutorials (4 HOURS) will provide comprehensive coverage of key topics related to Research Integrity and Ethics, allowing participants to engage with the material at their own pace. These tutorials will include a range of resources and interactive exercises to explore the complexities of ethical issues.

Teaching Method 4—Self-directed study. The self-study hours will include reading about the topics, researching and critically appraising articles on global challenges, time spent on group work and preparing for assignments, and exploring and practicing digital platforms. This will require adaptability and organizational skills.
Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module, as evidenced by this cohesive research-connected course, which enables active learning through working on real global issues and where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to current employability skills (effective communication, problem-solving, critical thinking, and analysis).

Research-Connected Teaching and Active Learning: Learning and teaching throughout this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists in molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology, ensuring that the latest research evidence informs teaching. In addressing global challenges in biosciences, such as emerging diseases, antimicrobial resistance, and personalized medicine, core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications from recent clinical and scientific research. Application-based sessions and workshops incorporate real-world examples that highlight the role of biosciences in tackling these global health issues, fostering a deeper understanding of both current challenges and cutting-edge solutions. The seminars and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Special attention has been given to designing and developing this module to ensure it is accessible and inclusive for all individuals. The content, topics, and case studies are tailored to be relevant for students from various life sciences disciplines, as well as for international students. Workshops will offer additional support on the covered topics and provide guidance for international students. These workshops will also offer formative feedback, allowing every student to improve their performance in assessments. Self-directed learning through interactive resources will enable students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of key course elements beforehand. All resource templates are designed with accessibility in mind to ensure ease of use for all. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module, emphasizing active participation and collaboration. Lectures are designed to be highly interactive and discursive, encouraging learners to engage in meaningful dialogue, contribute ideas, and critically analyse complex topics. Assessment 1 is centred around collaborative group work, where learners function as a cohesive team to plan, execute, and interpret complex global challenges. This collaborative process nurtures confidence and creates a supportive environment—a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas, expertise, and feedback. Additionally, completing a project and effectively
communicating the outcomes through group poster presentations helps students build confidence across a diverse range of skills, including teamwork, critical thinking, and public communication.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is part of a globally connected professional community, and this module reflects that by embedding the values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability throughout its learning and assessment activities. The learning materials prioritize diverse representation, incorporating scientific case studies from underrepresented communities and highlighting sustainable practices in the teaching and learning environment. The module also emphasizes a strong ethical focus, encouraging learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with particular attention to ethics relevant to their specific discipline.

Students will be informed that teaching plans may be subject to change in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics). Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each student informing them of any changes that prove necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There will be two assessments: A group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study for which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.

The assessments in this module address key areas in the University of Liverpool’s strategic framework for supporting the development of successful graduates, in particular in relation to developing digital skills, global citizenship and inclusivity. Both assignments require students to utilise digital skills, the first being a poster, and the second being production of an animated video. Students will have support in the form of formal training and formative feedback to aid the development of these digital skills, prior to the submission of these assessments. In relation to global citizenship, both assignments require students to consider challenges in the biosciences on a global scale and, in the case of the second assessment, to also provide solutions to the global issue they have chosen to explore, thus aiding them in becoming graduates with the ability to see challenges from a global perspective. The second assessment also requires students to reflect on the design of their animation from the perspective of creating inclusive content, again broadening their perspectives and their understanding of inclusive practices.

Assessment 1:
A group poster critiquing a public-facing science content.
Peer evaluation will be used as part of the marking.
Assessment 1 is worth 40% of the module mark.

Assessment 2:
This assessment is composed of two parts:
-A 3-5 minute animated digital case study outlining a current challenge faced in the biosciences and presenting possible solution(s) (worth 60% of the assessment 2 grade)
-A critical reflection on the design in relation to accessibility and clear messaging (worth 40% of the assessment 2 grade)
Assessment 2 is worth 60% of the module mark.
For both assessments, there will be an opportunity for formative feedback.
Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Reassessment strategy
There is a re-assessment opportunity for both assessments. For assessment 1, the poster will be an individual piece of work. For assessment 2, the format will be the same as the original. It will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2025. The new module is developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that ISMIB MRes provision should concentrate on a single program spanning biological and biomedical pathways. We aim to offer an MRes program of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned with our strategic ambitions. In addition, this module will be offered to the MBiol (Integrated Masters). Currently, students take LIFE731, a module that will close from Sept 2025. In summary, this module will be made available to:
Integrated Masters (MBiol)[required]
Biotechnology MSc (part-time) MSc 2025-26 [optional]
Biological and Biomedical Sciences (full-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]
Advanced Biological and Biomedical Sciences (part-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]


Staffing and Expertise: Contributions to teaching will be predominantly from ISMIB and other institutes within FHLS .

Overview

Overview
This module is designed to provide students with the essential knowledge and interdisciplinary skills required to address some of the most urgent global challenges in the field of biosciences. The course empowers students to navigate complex scientific issues with a holistic and ethical mindset by exploring pivotal topics such as global health crises, sustainable development, and the role of public engagement in science. By combining scientific inquiry with an understanding of societal and environmental contexts, learners will be better equipped to propose solutions to real-world problems.
The module will be delivered through a combination of lectures, interactive workshops, and seminars. These formats will provide foundational knowledge and encourage active participation and deeper engagement with the material. Students will be motivated to independently explore the subjects, conduct their research, and develop skills in critical analysis by reviewing, evaluating, and interpreting a range of sources.
There will be two assessments: a group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study in which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.
Educational Aims
•To ensure students develop an understanding of current issues faced in the biosciences relating to research, sustainability and public engagement
•To develop students with an enhanced ability to communicate effectively in a range of settings
•To provide students with enhanced skills in critical thinking and problem-solving
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to equip students with the critical knowledge and interdisciplinary skills needed to tackle today's most pressing global challenges in the biosciences with a holistic and ethical perspective by exploring key topics, such as:
Global health challenges, including drug design and development, tissue engineering, and cancer research.
Sustainable development challenges, focusing on sustainability in biosciences research, the use of artificial intelligence, the impacts of climate change, and
Public engagement in science.

Through these topics, learners gain a comprehensive understanding of the intersections between science, sustainability, and ethics.

Students will be taught through seminars, in which experts will discuss a particular area of challenge in the biosciences. There will also be interactive workshops dedicated to the development of skills, in support of the module assignments, and online asynchronous material to support learning.
Outline Syllabus
Sessions will introduce a range of topics related to global challenges in the biosciences, catering to the needs of the diverse cohort. Topics might include:

Topics related to Health:
-Global healthcare challenges
-Drug design and development
-Antimicrobial Resistance

Topics related to the environment:
-Food security
-Biodiversity
-Climate change

Research ethics

Topics related to sustainability:
-Sustainability in Research
-Sustainability in Education
-Sustainability in AI

The following sessions will specifically guide students in relation to their assessment tasks:
-Public Engagement including challenges and benefits
-Preparing a poster
-How to create a digital case study
-Critical reading and writing
-Critical thinking and reflection

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to the availability of staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching method 1—Seminars (9 HOURS ): A series of nine seminars will cover a variety of topics addressing global challenges in the biosciences, tailored to meet the diverse needs of participants from various life science disciplines. These seminars, led by experts, will present cutting-edge material, offering an enriching platform for research-informed teaching.

Teaching method 2—Workshops (10 HOURS): 5 (2h) academic-led workshops will deliver content related to the development of skills required for interpreting high-level scientific content (i.e., critical thinking) and skills related to digital fluency (such as creating posters and animated videos).

Teaching Method 3 – Asynchronous online tutorials (4 HOURS) will provide comprehensive coverage of key topics related to Research Integrity and Ethics, allowing participants to engage with the material at their own pace. These tutorials will include a range of resources and interactive exercises to explore the complexities of ethical issues.

Teaching Method 4—Self-directed study. The self-study hours will include reading about the topics, researching and critically appraising articles on global challenges, time spent on group work and preparing for assignments, and exploring and practicing digital platforms. This will require adaptability and organizational skills.
Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module, as evidenced by this cohesive research-connected course, which enables active learning through working on real global issues and where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to current employability skills (effective communication, problem-solving, critical thinking, and analysis).

Research-Connected Teaching and Active Learning: Learning and teaching throughout this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists in molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology, ensuring that the latest research evidence informs teaching. In addressing global challenges in biosciences, such as emerging diseases, antimicrobial resistance, and personalized medicine, core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications from recent clinical and scientific research. Application-based sessions and workshops incorporate real-world examples that highlight the role of biosciences in tackling these global health issues, fostering a deeper understanding of both current challenges and cutting-edge solutions. The seminars and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Special attention has been given to designing and developing this module to ensure it is accessible and inclusive for all individuals. The content, topics, and case studies are tailored to be relevant for students from various life sciences disciplines, as well as for international students. Workshops will offer additional support on the covered topics and provide guidance for international students. These workshops will also offer formative feedback, allowing every student to improve their performance in assessments. Self-directed learning through interactive resources will enable students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of key course elements beforehand. All resource templates are designed with accessibility in mind to ensure ease of use for all. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module, emphasizing active participation and collaboration. Lectures are designed to be highly interactive and discursive, encouraging learners to engage in meaningful dialogue, contribute ideas, and critically analyse complex topics. Assessment 1 is centred around collaborative group work, where learners function as a cohesive team to plan, execute, and interpret complex global challenges. This collaborative process nurtures confidence and creates a supportive environment—a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas, expertise, and feedback. Additionally, completing a project and effectively
communicating the outcomes through group poster presentations helps students build confidence across a diverse range of skills, including teamwork, critical thinking, and public communication.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is part of a globally connected professional community, and this module reflects that by embedding the values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability throughout its learning and assessment activities. The learning materials prioritize diverse representation, incorporating scientific case studies from underrepresented communities and highlighting sustainable practices in the teaching and learning environment. The module also emphasizes a strong ethical focus, encouraging learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with particular attention to ethics relevant to their specific discipline.

Students will be informed that teaching plans may be subject to change in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics). Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each student informing them of any changes that prove necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There will be two assessments: A group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study for which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.

The assessments in this module address key areas in the University of Liverpool’s strategic framework for supporting the development of successful graduates, in particular in relation to developing digital skills, global citizenship and inclusivity. Both assignments require students to utilise digital skills, the first being a poster, and the second being production of an animated video. Students will have support in the form of formal training and formative feedback to aid the development of these digital skills, prior to the submission of these assessments. In relation to global citizenship, both assignments require students to consider challenges in the biosciences on a global scale and, in the case of the second assessment, to also provide solutions to the global issue they have chosen to explore, thus aiding them in becoming graduates with the ability to see challenges from a global perspective. The second assessment also requires students to reflect on the design of their animation from the perspective of creating inclusive content, again broadening their perspectives and their understanding of inclusive practices.

Assessment 1:
A group poster critiquing a public-facing science content.
Peer evaluation will be used as part of the marking.
Assessment 1 is worth 40% of the module mark.

Assessment 2:
This assessment is composed of two parts:
-A 3-5 minute animated digital case study outlining a current challenge faced in the biosciences and presenting possible solution(s) (worth 60% of the assessment 2 grade)
-A critical reflection on the design in relation to accessibility and clear messaging (worth 40% of the assessment 2 grade)
Assessment 2 is worth 60% of the module mark.
For both assessments, there will be an opportunity for formative feedback.
Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Reassessment strategy
There is a re-assessment opportunity for both assessments. For assessment 1, the poster will be an individual piece of work. For assessment 2, the format will be the same as the original. It will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2025. The new module is developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that ISMIB MRes provision should concentrate on a single program spanning biological and biomedical pathways. We aim to offer an MRes program of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned with our strategic ambitions. In addition, this module will be offered to the MBiol (Integrated Masters). Currently, students take LIFE731, a module that will close from Sept 2025. In summary, this module will be made available to:
Integrated Masters (MBiol)[required]
Biotechnology MSc (part-time) MSc 2025-26 [optional]
Biological and Biomedical Sciences (full-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]
Advanced Biological and Biomedical Sciences (part-time) MRes 2025-26 [optional]


Staffing and Expertise: Contributions to teaching will be predominantly from ISMIB and other institutes within FHLS .

Overview

Overview
This module is designed to provide students with the essential knowledge and interdisciplinary skills required to address some of the most urgent global challenges in the field of biosciences. The course empowers students to navigate complex scientific issues with a holistic and ethical mindset by exploring pivotal topics such as global health crises, sustainable development, and the role of public engagement in science. By combining scientific inquiry with an understanding of societal and environmental contexts, learners will be better equipped to propose solutions to real-world problems.
The module will be delivered through a combination of lectures, interactive workshops, and seminars. These formats will provide foundational knowledge and encourage active participation and deeper engagement with the material. Students will be motivated to independently explore the subjects, conduct their research, and develop skills in critical analysis by reviewing, evaluating, and interpreting a range of sources.
There will be two assessments: a group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study in which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.
Educational Aims
•To ensure students develop an understanding of current issues faced in the biosciences relating to research, sustainability and public engagement
•To develop students with an enhanced ability to communicate effectively in a range of settings
•To provide students with enhanced skills in critical thinking and problem-solving
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to equip students with the critical knowledge and interdisciplinary skills needed to tackle today's most pressing global challenges in the biosciences with a holistic and ethical perspective by exploring key topics, such as:
Global health challenges, including drug design and development, tissue engineering, and cancer research.
Sustainable development challenges, focusing on sustainability in biosciences research, the use of artificial intelligence, the impacts of climate change, and
Public engagement in science.

Through these topics, learners gain a comprehensive understanding of the intersections between science, sustainability, and ethics.

Students will be taught through seminars, in which experts will discuss a particular area of challenge in the biosciences. There will also be interactive workshops dedicated to the development of skills, in support of the module assignments, and online asynchronous material to support learning.
Outline Syllabus
Sessions will introduce a range of topics related to global challenges in the biosciences, catering to the needs of the diverse cohort. Topics might include:

Topics related to Health:
-Global healthcare challenges
-Drug design and development
-Antimicrobial Resistance

Topics related to the environment:
-Food security
-Biodiversity
-Climate change

Research ethics

Topics related to sustainability:
-Sustainability in Research
-Sustainability in Education
-Sustainability in AI

The following sessions will specifically guide students in relation to their assessment tasks:
-Public Engagement including challenges and benefits
-Preparing a poster
-How to create a digital case study
-Critical reading and writing
-Critical thinking and reflection

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to the availability of staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching method 1—Seminars (9 HOURS ): A series of nine seminars will cover a variety of topics addressing global challenges in the biosciences, tailored to meet the diverse needs of participants from various life science disciplines. These seminars, led by experts, will present cutting-edge material, offering an enriching platform for research-informed teaching.

Teaching method 2—Workshops (10 HOURS): 5 (2h) academic-led workshops will deliver content related to the development of skills required for interpreting high-level scientific content (i.e., critical thinking) and skills related to digital fluency (such as creating posters and animated videos).

Teaching Method 3 – Asynchronous online tutorials (4 HOURS) will provide comprehensive coverage of key topics related to Research Integrity and Ethics, allowing participants to engage with the material at their own pace. These tutorials will include a range of resources and interactive exercises to explore the complexities of ethical issues.

Teaching Method 4—Self-directed study. The self-study hours will include reading about the topics, researching and critically appraising articles on global challenges, time spent on group work and preparing for assignments, and exploring and practicing digital platforms. This will require adaptability and organizational skills.
Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module, as evidenced by this cohesive research-connected course, which enables active learning through working on real global issues and where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to current employability skills (effective communication, problem-solving, critical thinking, and analysis).

Research-Connected Teaching and Active Learning: Learning and teaching throughout this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists in molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology, ensuring that the latest research evidence informs teaching. In addressing global challenges in biosciences, such as emerging diseases, antimicrobial resistance, and personalized medicine, core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications from recent clinical and scientific research. Application-based sessions and workshops incorporate real-world examples that highlight the role of biosciences in tackling these global health issues, fostering a deeper understanding of both current challenges and cutting-edge solutions. The seminars and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Special attention has been given to designing and developing this module to ensure it is accessible and inclusive for all individuals. The content, topics, and case studies are tailored to be relevant for students from various life sciences disciplines, as well as for international students. Workshops will offer additional support on the covered topics and provide guidance for international students. These workshops will also offer formative feedback, allowing every student to improve their performance in assessments. Self-directed learning through interactive resources will enable students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of key course elements beforehand. All resource templates are designed with accessibility in mind to ensure ease of use for all. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module, emphasizing active participation and collaboration. Lectures are designed to be highly interactive and discursive, encouraging learners to engage in meaningful dialogue, contribute ideas, and critically analyse complex topics. Assessment 1 is centred around collaborative group work, where learners function as a cohesive team to plan, execute, and interpret complex global challenges. This collaborative process nurtures confidence and creates a supportive environment—a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas, expertise, and feedback. Additionally, completing a project and effectively
communicating the outcomes through group poster presentations helps students build confidence across a diverse range of skills, including teamwork, critical thinking, and public communication.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is part of a globally connected professional community, and this module reflects that by embedding the values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability throughout its learning and assessment activities. The learning materials prioritize diverse representation, incorporating scientific case studies from underrepresented communities and highlighting sustainable practices in the teaching and learning environment. The module also emphasizes a strong ethical focus, encouraging learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with particular attention to ethics relevant to their specific discipline.

Students will be informed that teaching plans may be subject to change in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics). Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each student informing them of any changes that prove necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There will be two assessments: A group poster in which students will explore and critique a piece of public-facing science content. The second assessment will be a digital case study for which students will investigate a current challenge faced in the biosciences and present possible solution(s) in a 3 minute animated video.

The assessments in this module address key areas in the University of Liverpool’s strategic framework for supporting the development of successful graduates, in particular in relation to developing digital skills, global citizenship and inclusivity. Both assignments require students to utilise digital skills, the first being a poster, and the second being production of an animated video. Students will have support in the form of formal training and formative feedback to aid the development of these digital skills, prior to the submission of these assessments. In relation to global citizenship, both assignments require students to consider challenges in the biosciences on a global scale and, in the case of the second assessment, to also provide solutions to the global issue they have chosen to explore, thus aiding them in becoming graduates with the ability to see challenges from a global perspective. The second assessment also requires students to reflect on the design of their animation from the perspective of creating inclusive content, again broadening their perspectives and their understanding of inclusive practices.

Assessment 1:
A group poster critiquing a public-facing science content.
Peer evaluation will be used as part of the marking.
Assessment 1 is worth 40% of the module mark.

Assessment 2:
This assessment is composed of two parts:
-A 3-5 minute animated digital case study outlining a current challenge faced in the biosciences and presenting possible solution(s) (worth 60% of the assessment 2 grade)
-A critical reflection on the design in relation to accessibility and clear messaging (worth 40% of the assessment 2 grade)
Assessment 2 is worth 60% of the module mark.
For both assessments, there will be an opportunity for formative feedback.
Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Reassessment strategy
There is a re-assessment opportunity for both assessments. For assessment 1, the poster will be an individual piece of work. For assessment 2, the format will be the same as the original. It will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
